title: ASEAN members in final push to coax India into trade deal
text:
"We know the issue between China and India is goods trade," she said on Tuesday.

"There has been a lot of effort to deal with this, including stronger trade remedies.

"I believe these remedies will be stronger for countries that don't have a [free trade agreement] with each other yet. So if there is an import surge, that can be dealt with."

The RCEP loomed large at an event in Jakarta on Tuesday organised by IBER, along with the Asian Bureau of Economic Research.

In a global economy struggling to deal with the US-Sino trade war, the proposed deal should be looked at from a geopolitical, as well as an economic perspective, according to Chatib Basri, senior lecturer at the University of Indonesia and a former Indonesian finance minister.

“ASEAN countries, when they have to deal with giants, they can’t do it singly. They should be talking to China, for example, as a single entity. That’s why RCEP is very important.

“And with China set to sign up, India is needed to balance the RCEP,” Basri said.

Toshinori Doi, director of the ASEAN+3 Macroeconomic Research office in Singapore, said regional trade was more important than ever to ASEAN countries' economic expansion against signs of weakening global growth.

“The conclusion of RCEP would be another way to diversify trade. It’s not about decoupling from the US; it’s about diversifying trade opportunities," he said.

But getting India over the line is going to be difficult. Another speaker at the IBER conference suggested an all-party agreed RCEP was only likely to be achieved through the direct intervention of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

"Neither China nor India can choose their neighbours," said Suman Bery, a non-resident fellow of the Brussels think-tank Bruegel who is based in New Delhi.

"Integration between the two would give the region a huge push. But cut the leaders a little slack; the issues are fiendishly complicated."

Nine months ago, the RCEP was just another free trade agreement but it has been elevated in importance due to global upheavals, said Peter Drysdale, head of the Asian Bureau of Economic Research.

"If it does get over the line at ASEAN, it will be because Prime Minister Modi has grasped the importance of RCEP for the global economic and political order," Mr Drysdale said.
description: India’s regional partners hope that measures to deal with a fears of a potential 'import surge' from China and other countries will help get the government of Nerendra Modi over the line on a new trade agreement at this weekend's ASEAN summit.
